comments.commentBody: The article quotes Molly Lambert asking what the reputation of a great artist is worth. It’s not worth the destruction of the emotional well-being of a 7-year old child or the woman that child has become. I hate the fact that victims of child abuse, rape and incest are still being attacked in this country. I thought we as a country were getting over that. Unfortunately, the change is coming much too slow but that’s no reason to stop fighting for what’s right. Every time a victim speaks up, another victim knows that he or she is not alone. Blaming the victims and covering up for perpetrators will stop (hopefully soon) since more people every day are saying that this in unacceptable. Victim blaming and shaming goes on all the time in third world countries – even to the point of so-called honor killings for rape victims but in this country victims of sex crimes should get the same dignified hearing and the same chance of justice as victims of any other crime. Also, Mr. Allen’s guilt or innocence should be judged completely separately from whether or not he’s a ‘great artist’.

Among the best films I've seen in recent years are Cristian Mungiu's "4 Months, 3 Weeks ..." and "Beyond the Hills". And if PBS did its job well, these would be shown on TV in primetime. American audiences would be better educated about the wide world through films such as these than through adolescent swill such as "Downton Abbey."

There is also, by the way, an Iranian New Wave whose remarkable, sometimes terrific films are unknown to most Americans. And there are fine films from Latin America, including those by director Carlos Reygas which deserve a wide audience here in the US.

We could go a long to way toward being a better educated citizenry by providing for frequent showings of the best of foreign cinema in public venues.

Unless, of ignorance is desired for keeping the deluded unfree.

Briefly put, this is the crappiest, most ill thought out collection of philosophical arguments I have ever seen in my life. Some of the previous commenters have mentioned a few of the many argumentation tricks and outright fallacies (one or more per paragraph) A.P employs to twist the discussion away from the tawdry weakness of his few actual arguments against atheism.

That is only one objection. The second is that, as some have pointed out, atheism is simply the refusal to accept bad (in the just possibly legitimate judgement of the atheist) for "God" (and which or what "god" exactly?).

Here is a third objection, related to the second. A.P. and G.G. seem to assume that an "atheist" is dedicated to the proposition that there is no "God" (whatever that means). In fact, some are, but many others are simply judging on the evidence and if there were to be good evidence for a "God" they would be willing to consider it.

I can't resist picking the gaping hole in one more of A.P.'s arguments. Yes, this could be the best of all possible worlds, as he proposes without evidence. It could equally well be the worst of all possible worlds. In that case, "God" would surely exist, due to the otherwise low probability of the worst being the real world, and would plainly be the "Devil". Does that inspire A.P.'s belief in the Devil? If not, the argument is worthless by his own account.

Thank you for this inside!!! To know, that arguments over fashion also did / do exist in MATHEMATICS and are not only a nuissance in social sciences does mean a lot to me - also, that changing my profession would not help.

@David: Yes, there were good reasons for insisting on axiomatics, abstraction, and rigor. But it went to the point of excluding that which was not abstract, axiomatic, and rigorous enough, and including that which was abstract, axiomatic, and rigorous even if of little to no value. There were some legitimate reasons for that, e.g., it wasn't possible to tell for some time what axiom systems were worthwhile and which were a waste of time. Nevertheless, it's true that the fashion swung too far in at least some journals and departments. I cite as a one example the strong prejudice against combinatorics in many of the top math departments in North America, in the 50s and much later, whose effect lingers on to this day in some.

It would be mistaken to say combinatorics doesn't need rigor because it is finite, or nearly finite. However, I agree that the foundations are much more delicate and clear axiomatics can be much more valuable when one gets to uncountables in analysis or weird properties or partial properties in algebra.
@David:  See my second post, which is a reply to yours.

This post reminds me disagreeably of the time when abstract axiomatic rigor overtook theoretical mathematics. Axiom systems and pedantically rigorous logical deductions were in, intuitively clear reasoning was out.
At the same time applied math went its separate merry way with computations, approximations, and experiments. It was the middle ground that was verboten. Fortunately for my field, combinatorics, which relies more on explanation and understanding than on axioms (though it has both), the pendulum has swung back to the center.

For the technically inclined here is one example: In the highest levels of mathematics, vector spaces could not be treated via coordinates and linear transformations could not be treated via matrices.

On the other hand, combinatorics has been defined (somewhat grandiosely) as vector spaces with distinguished bases.

Foster said, "Have you ever tried to take away the keys to the car of a family member because you realize they can not drive in some ways (dark, interstates, snow), but they consider driving necessary to live there life (go to the store or the doctors) and want to remain as independent as possible"

Foster clearly articulates the reality that older people may lose their ability to drive safely, and his question about trying to convince a family member of this fact (trying to take away their keys) simply proves my point. Everyone wants to be as independent as possible as they age. That's why many communities supply transport to the elderly - not only to stores and doctors, but to cultural events as well, because we know that people may not be able to drive, but they still need to live!

Why is it different with guns? Why, in fact, wouldn't you do everything possible to remove a loved one's guns if he/she were no longer able to use them safely?

And George -- My own father gave up driving on his own, but not before my brother and I did a lot of nagging. If he had guns, we would have skipped the nagging stage.
